formalpara.title: Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6 (RHEL6)
formalpara.para: If you are running RHEL6, you will need to enable the Extra Packages for Enterprise Linux (EPEL) repository. EPEL can be enabled by installing the epel-release RPM, which contains the repository GPG key as well as configuration for yum. The EPEL repository RPMs can be found at http://download.fedoraproject.org/pub/epel/6/i386/repoview/epel-release.html

listitem.para: Once EPEL is enabled, SCAP Security Guide can be installed via yum: $ sudo yum install scap-security-guide

formalpara.title: Fedora 19+
formalpara.para: SCAP Security Guide is shipped natively in Fedora 19+ and can be installed via yum: $ sudo yum install scap-security-guide

section.title: Source Code

listitem.para: On RHEL and Fedora make sure the packages 'openscap-utils' and 'python-lxml' and their dependencies are installed. As the project contains OVAL 5.8 content we require version 0.8 or later of openscap-utils (available in RHEL 6.2+). Additionally, if not present, git must be installed. $ sudo yum install git openscap-utils python-lxml
Download our source code: $ git clone git://git.fedorahosted.org/git/scap-security-guide.git
'make' the SSG $ cd scap-security-guide $ make $ cd output

section.para:
Discover the following:
A pretty prose guide in RHEL6/output/rhel6-guide.html containing practical, actionable information for administrators
A concise spreadsheet representation (potentially useful as the bases for an SRTM document) in RHEL6/output/rhel6-table-nistrefs-server.html
Files that can be ingested by SCAP-compatible scanning tools, to enable automated checking:
RHEL6/output/rhel6-xccdf-scap-security-guide.xml
RHEL6/output/rhel6-oval-scap-security-guide.xml
JBossEAP5/eap5-xccdf.xml
